item.title: Sergeant Rapson
item.description:
Asset Author: 
Mary Siraut
Copyright: 
Somerset County History Trust

The sergeant was a man whose faith was very important to him and was glad to have the opportunity of hearing a bishop preach but he also longed for a cornet.

item.title: A bellringer's letter
item.description:
Asset Author: 
Mary Siraut
Copyright: 
Somerset County History Trust

For one soldier it was the bells he missed amid the gunfire of which he gave a graphic account. The noise of trench warfare comes over vividly in his letter.

item.description:

For many men their Christian faith sustained them and opportunities to take communion were important.

item.title: Prisoners of War from Taunton
item.description:
Asset Author: 
Mary Siraut
Copyright: 
Somerset County History Trust

Sadly, several men from Taunton were taken prisoners in the early months of the year and five found themselves at the Gefangenen-Lager, Doeberitz.

item.title: A little Taunton in Burma
item.description:
Asset Author: 
Mary Siraut
Copyright: 
Somerset County History Trust

In contrast to life in the trenches many Taunton men found themselves at Meiktila in Burma where there was concern for prioviding entertainment for the men for whom a piano was hired.

           

Asset File: 
little_taunton_in_burma.doc
item.dc:creator: MaryS

item.title: Letters to the vicar
item.description:
Asset Author: 
Mary Siraut
Copyright: 
Somerset County History Trust

Canon Corfield, vicar of Taunton St Mary, received a regular stream of letters. As well as ordinary parishioners on active service his three gardeners and at least four of his choir were in the army, and he had five nephews serving.  He was no pacifist and expressed pleasure at hearing that men were leaving for the front.

Asset File: 
some_letters_to_the_vicar_1915.doc
item.dc:creator: MaryS

item.title: Taunton St Mary Magdalene church
item.description:
Somerset Light Infantry window in Taunton St Mary Magdalene
Copyright: 
Mary Siraut

As with many congregations there were many absent parishioners from St Mary’s by January 1915. In addition to those known to be dead c. 270 parishioners were in the war. However, with nearly 1,000 soldiers in Taunton, St Mary's actually increased its congregations with 400 soldiers swelling the attendance at Matins besides church parades.

Asset File: 
st_mary_taunton_june_09_027.jpg
item.dc:creator: MaryS

item.title: A Taunton vicar's letters from the front
item.description: A remarkable correspondence had begun by 1915 between parishioners and the vicar of Taunton St Mary Magdalene and other church officers. Although the originals are missing many were copied into the parish magazine or extracts were printed. There were letters about killed and missing men, appeals for food from prisoners of war and sometimes quite graphic accounts of life in the trenches. There were letters from France, Burma and naval ships.
item.dc:creator: MaryS

item.title: Norton Fitzwarren war memorial
item.description:
Norton Fitzwarren war memorial
Copyright: 
Rosalind Johnson, University of London

The war memorial gates list the 21 men who were killed on actove service during the First World War.

item.title: Norton Fitzwarren war memorial
item.description:
Asset Author: 
Mary Siraut / Mary Siraut
Copyright: 
University of London

In 1918 54 men of voting age were absent on active service. Sadly many of those recorded died in the last year of the war.  At the Club in Station Road there is an unusual war memorial.
